Key Propositions.Statement: The man, who is guided by reason, is more free in a State, where he lives under a general system of law, than in solitude, where he is independent.

Parts.Summary: Describes human servitude to passions due to inadequate ideas and external causes; outlines precepts for living according to reason

Parts.Title: Of the Power of the Intellect, or of Human Freedom
Key Axioms: The affections of the Body, or images of things, are arranged and connected in the Body in exactly the same way as thoughts and ideas of things are arranged and connected in the Mind

Key Propositions.Statement: Even as thoughts and the ideas of things are arranged and associated in the mind, so are the modifications of body or the images of things precisely in the same way arranged and associated in the body.
Key Propositions.Significance: Parallel arrangement in mind and body

Key Propositions.Statement: If we remove a disturbance of the spirit, or emotion, from the thought of an external cause, and unite it to other thoughts, then will the love or hatred towards that external cause, and also the vacillations of spirit which arise from these emotions, be destroyed.
Key Propositions.Significance: Remedy by separating emotion from cause

Key Propositions.Statement: An emotion, which is a passion, ceases to be a passion, as soon as we form a clear and distinct idea thereof.
There is no modification of the body, whereof we cannot form some clear and distinct conception.
Key Propositions.Significance: Possible clarity for all body modifications

Key Propositions.Statement: An emotion towards a thing, which we conceive simply, and not as necessary, or as contingent, or as possible, is, other conditions being equal, greater than any other emotion.
The mind has greater power over the emotions and is less subject thereto, in so far as it understands all things as necessary.
Emotions which are aroused or spring from reason, if we take account of time, are stronger than those, which are attributable to particular objects that we regard as absent.
Key Propositions.Significance: Strength of rational emotions over time

Key Propositions.Statement: An emotion is stronger in proportion to the number of simultaneous concurrent causes whereby it is aroused.

An emotion, which is attributable to many and diverse causes which the mind regards as simultaneous with the emotion itself, is less hurtful, and we are less subject thereto and less affected towards each of its causes, than if it were a different and equally powerful emotion attributable to fewer causes or to a single cause.
So long as we are not assailed by emotions contrary to our nature, we have the power of arranging and associating the modifications of our body according to the intellectual order.
In proportion as a mental image is referred to more objects, so is it more frequent, or more often vivid, and occupies the mind more.
The mental images of things are more easily associated with the images referred to things which we clearly and distinctly understand, than with others.
A mental image is more often vivid, in proportion as it is associated with a greater number of other images.
The mind can bring it about, that all bodily modifications or images of things may be referred to the idea of God.
He who clearly and distinctly understands himself and his emotions loves God, and so much the more in proportion as he more understands himself and his emotions.
Key Propositions.Significance: Self-understanding leads to love of God

Key Propositions.Statement: This love towards God must hold the chief place in the mind.
God is without passions, neither is he affected by any emotion of pleasure or pain.
No one can hate God.
He, who loves God, cannot endeavour that God should love him in return.
Key Propositions.Significance: No desire for reciprocal love from God

Key Propositions.Statement: This love towards God cannot be stained by the emotion of envy or jealousy: contrariwise, it is the more fostered, in proportion as we conceive a greater number of men to be joined to God by the same bond of love.
The mind can only imagine anything, or remember what is past, while the body endures.
Key Propositions.Significance: Imagination and memory tied to body

Key Propositions.Statement: Nevertheless in God there is necessarily an idea, which expresses the essence of this or that human body under the form of eternity.
Key Propositions.Significance: Eternal idea of body in God

Key Propositions.Statement: The human mind cannot be absolutely destroyed with the body, but there remains of it something which is eternal.
Key Propositions.Significance: Eternity of part of the mind

Key Propositions.Statement: The more we understand particular things, the more do we understand God.
The highest endeavour of the mind, and the highest virtue is to understand things by the third kind of knowledge.
In proportion as the mind is more capable of understanding things by the third kind of knowledge, it desires more to understand things by that kind.
From this third kind of knowledge arises the highest possible mental acquiescence.
The endeavour or desire to know things by the third kind of knowledge cannot arise from the first, but from the second kind of knowledge.

Whatsoever the mind understands under the form of eternity, it does not understand by virtue of conceiving the present actual existence of the body, but by virtue of conceiving the essence of the body under the form of eternity.
Key Propositions.Significance: Eternal understanding independent of body's existence

Key Propositions.Statement: Our mind, in so far as it knows itself and the body under the form of eternity, has to that extent necessarily a knowledge of God, and knows that it is in God, and is conceived through God.
The third kind of knowledge depends on the mind, as its formal cause
Key Propositions.Significance: Mind as cause of intuitive knowledge

Key Propositions.Statement: Whatsoever we understand by the third kind of knowledge, we take delight in, and our delight is accompanied by the idea of God as cause.
Key Propositions.Significance: Delight in intuitive knowledge with God

Key Propositions.Statement: The intellectual love of God, which arises from the third kind of knowledge, is eternal.
The mind is, only while the body endures, subject to those emotions which are attributable to passions.
God loves himself with an infinite intellectual love.

The intellectual love of the mind towards God is that very love of God whereby God loves himself, not in so far as he is infinite, but in so far as he can be explained through the essence of the human mind regarded under the form of eternity; in other words, the intellectual love of the mind towards God is part of the infinite love wherewith God loves himself.
Key Propositions.Significance: Mind's love as part of God's love

Key Propositions.Statement: There is nothing in nature, which is contrary to this intellectual love, or which can take it away.
In proportion as the mind understands more things by the second and third kind of knowledge, it is less subject to those emotions which are evil, and stands in less fear of death.
Key Propositions.Significance: Higher knowledge reduces evil emotions and fear

Key Propositions.Statement: He, who possesses a body capable of the greatest number of activities, possesses a mind whereof the greatest part is eternal.
Key Propositions.Significance: Complex body implies more eternal mind

Key Propositions.Statement: In proportion as each thing possesses more of perfection, so is it more active, and less passive; and, vice versā, in proportion as it is more active, so is it more perfect.

Even if we did not know that our mind is eternal, we should still consider as of primary importance piety and religion, and generally all things which, in Part IV., we showed to be attributable to courage and high-mindedness.
Key Propositions.Significance: Importance of virtue regardless of eternity

Key Propositions.Statement: Blessedness is not the reward of virtue, but virtue itself; nor do we enjoy it because we restrain our lusts; on the contrary, because we enjoy it, we are able to restrain them
Key Propositions.Significance: Culmination: Intellectual love of God as eternal

Parts.Summary: Explains remedies for affects, the eternity of the mind through adequate ideas, and the intellectual love of God as the highest freedom.

biological_imperative_realism.Purpose: To provide a realistic framework for understanding human nature and behavior through biological and evolutionary lenses, emphasizing the role of violence, hierarchies, and group dynamics as inherent mechanisms for survival and progress. Critiques aggression, avoiding endorsement.

Definitions.Definition_1: Reproductive and Territorial Aggression: The innate drive in organisms to engage in violent behaviors to secure mates, resources, and territory, ensuring genetic propagation.
Definitions.Definition_2: Pecking Order: A hierarchical structure in social groups where dominance determines access to resources, mates, and survival advantages, observed across species from chickens to humans.
Definitions.Definition_3: Superorganism: A collective entity formed by individuals, such as a hive or society, where individual members are expendable for the greater good of the group, functioning as a single adaptive unit.
Definitions.Definition_4: Biological Imperatives: Fundamental drives rooted in nature's savagery, including predation, competition, and innovation through conflict, that propel evolutionary adaptation.

Axioms.Axiom_1: Violence is an intrinsic component of biological systems, arising from the need to reproduce and control resources, as evidenced by animal behaviors mirroring human conflicts.
Axioms.Axiom_2: Hierarchies are universal in nature, enforcing order and resource allocation, where lower ranks face disadvantage or elimination to maintain group efficiency.
Axioms.Axiom_3: Organisms form superorganisms where individual sacrifice serves collective survival, driving group-level competition and violence.
Axioms.Axiom_4: Nature operates on principles of savagery and competition, using violence as a catalyst for innovation, adaptation, and the elimination of the unfit.

Propositions.Proposition_1: Human wars and social conflicts derive necessarily from reproductive and territorial imperatives, as males compete for mates and resources, perpetuated by female selection of aggressive traits.
Propositions.Proof_1: From Axiom 1 and Definition 1, animal examples like chimpanzee warfare and gorilla infanticide demonstrate that such aggression ensures genetic dominance, paralleling human history of conquest and heroism rewarded in mating.

Propositions.Proposition_2: Social and political despotism in humans stems from pecking orders, where ideologies justify violence against inferiors to sustain hierarchical stability.
Propositions.Proof_2: From Axiom 2 and Definition 2, observations in primates and insects show that dominance attracts resources, while subordination leads to peril; in nations, this manifests as conquests like Rome's over Carthage.

Propositions.Proposition_3: Human societies function as superorganisms, expending individuals in wars to manage populations and secure advantages in inter-group competitions.
Propositions.Proof_3: From Axiom 3 and Definition 3, male disposability in bees and primates parallels human tribal raids, where hypersociality fosters collective violence for superorganism survival.

Propositions.Proposition_4: Bigotry, warfare, and cultural clashes are extensions of natural savagery, serving as tools for evolutionary progress through adaptation and innovation.
Propositions.Proof_4: From Axiom 4 and Definition 4, ecosystems rely on predation and competition; in humans, this translates to territorial hoarding and conflict driving societal advancements.

Corollaries.Corollary_1: Evolution favors networks and groups over isolated individuals, where violence between superorganisms weeds out weaker entities, enhancing overall biological resilience.
Corollaries.Corollary_2: Human exceptionalism is a myth; behaviors like infanticide and warfare are continuations of primate patterns, dispelling notions of inherent pacifism in any gender or group.

biological_imperative_realism.ClosingNote: This biological perspective strengthens arguments by grounding abstract concepts in empirical animal studies, making them robust against critiques of human uniqueness, with potential for expansion via further research.

document.content: Influencing people's behaviour is nothing new to Government, which has often used tools such as legislation, regulation or taxation to achieve desired policy outcomes. But many of the biggest policy challenges we are now facing – such as the increase in people with chronic health conditions – will only be resolved if we are successful in persuading people to change their behaviour, their lifestyles or their existing habits. Fortunately, over the last decade, our understanding of influences on behaviour has increased significantly and this points the way to new approaches and new solutions. So whilst behavioural theory has already been deployed to good effect in some areas, it has much greater potential to help us. To realise that potential, we have to build our capacity and ensure that we have a sophisticated understanding of what does influence behaviour. This report is an important step in that direction because it shows how behavioural theory could help achieve better outcomes for citizens, either by complementing more established policy tools, or by suggesting more innovative interventions. In doing so, it draws on the most recent academic evidence, as well as exploring the wide range of existing good work in applying behavioural theory across the public sector. Finally, it shows how these insights could be put to practical use. This report tackles complex issues on which there are wide-ranging public views. We hope it will help stimulate debate amongst policy-makers and stakeholders and help us build our capability to use behaviour theory in an appropriate and effective way.

influencing_behaviour: Influencing behaviour is central to public policy. Recently, there have been major advances in understanding the influences on our behaviours, and government needs to take notice of them. This report aims to make that happen.

For policy-makers facing policy challenges such as crime, obesity, or environmental sustainability, behavioural approaches offer a potentially powerful new set of tools. Applying these tools can lead to low cost, low pain ways of “nudging” citizens - or ourselves - into new ways of acting by going with the grain of how we think and act. This is an important idea at any time, but is especially relevant in a period of fiscal constraint.

Recently, many books and reports have highlighted the potential benefits that behavioural approaches can bring to public policy. This report is not just an overview of theory; it addresses the needs of policy-makers by:
report_purpose: Condensing the relevant evidence into a manageable “checklist”, to ensure policy-makers take account of the most robust effects on our behaviour
Demonstrating how behavioural theory can help meet current policy challenges, including full case studies of its application in the UK
Showing how government can build behavioural theory into its current policy-making practices
Exploring important issues around the need for public permission and the role of personal responsibility
key_themes.policy_makers_interest: This report has emerged from many discussions with senior civil servants and ministers. All indicated that there was a real appetite to absorb and apply the latest thinking, in order to equip the civil service to meet the pressing challenges ahead. But they also felt that more help was needed to translate this appetite into action. In practice, how can these ideas actually help government make policy better? They are interesting effects but, fundamentally, “So what?” This report tries to answer the “so what?” question for policy-makers.

mindspace_checklist.description: Mnemonic for nine robust non-coercive influences on behaviour; quick checklist for policy-making.

elements.Messenger: we are heavily influenced by who communicates information
elements.Incentives: our responses to incentives are shaped by predictable mental shortcuts such as strongly avoiding losses
elements.Norms: we are strongly influenced by what others do
elements.Defaults: we ‘go with the flow’ of pre-set options
elements.Salience: our attention is drawn to what is novel and seems relevant to us
elements.Priming: our acts are often influenced by sub-conscious cues
elements.Affect: our emotional associations can powerfully shape our actions
elements.Commitments: we seek to be consistent with our public promises, and reciprocate acts
elements.Ego: we act in ways that make us feel better about ourselves

rationale: The vast majority of public policy aims to change or shape our behaviour. And policy-makers have many ways of doing so. Most obviously, they can use “hard” instruments such as legislation and regulation to compel us to act in certain ways. These approaches are often very effective, but are costly and inappropriate in many instances. So government often turns to less coercive, and sometimes very effective, measures, such as incentives (e.g. excise duty) and information provision (e.g. public health guidance) – as well as sophisticated communications techniques.

Why, then, is there a need to change anything? Behavioural theory suggests two reasons. First, the impact of existing tools such as incentives and information can be greatly enhanced by new evidence about how our behaviour is influenced (some of which has already been incorporated into government communications). Second, there are new, and potentially more effective, ways government could shape behaviour.

Tools such as incentives and information are intended to change behaviour by “changing minds”. If we provide the carrots and sticks, alongside accurate information, people will weigh up the revised costs and benefits of their actions and respond accordingly. Unfortunately, evidence suggests that people do not always respond in this ‘perfectly rational’ way.

In contrast, approaches based on “changing contexts” - the environment within which we make decisions and respond to cues - have the potential to bring about significant changes in behaviour at relatively low cost. Shaping policy more closely around our inbuilt responses to the world offers a potentially powerful way to improve individual wellbeing and social welfare.

areas: pro-social behaviour, such as voting and volunteering
examples: How the logic of gang membership was used to combat gang violence (Norms).
How inertia helped us save more for retirement (Defaults).
How giant bananas reduced littering (Salience).
meeting_policy_challenges.additional: We also show how MINDSPACE can generate new approaches to specific policy problems.

building_mindspace_into_policy.framework: Builds on DEFRA's 4Es (Enable, Encourage, Engage, Exemplify); adds Explore (pre-implementation) and Evaluate (success judgment).
building_mindspace_into_policy.6Es_diagram: Diagram/flowchart integrating MINDSPACE with policy methods; starts with 'Explore' (insight + MINDSPACE), flows into DEFRA's four Es—Enable (legislation, regulation, incentives, information, infrastructure, facilities, design, resources), Encourage (deliberation, permission, co-production), Engage (leading by example, policy consistency, organisational learning, evidence-based innovation), Exemplify—plus bottom 'Evaluate' for policy success judgment. Emphasizes MINDSPACE as tools enhancing existing methods without replacement. The principle illustrated is MINDSPACE as behaviour-change tools within practical 6 Es (Explore, Enable, Encourage, Engage, Exemplify, Evaluate) framework for policy-making.
building_mindspace_into_policy.integration: Applying MINDSPACE in practice builds on existing methods of policy-making. To illustrate this, we have drawn on the “4Es” policy framework, originally developed by DEFRA. The 4Es are four actions that should underpin government’s attempts to change behaviour: Enable, Encourage, Engage and Exemplify. MINDSPACE requires two supporting actions: Explore, which takes place before policies are implemented, and Evaluate, which judges the success of the policy. In basic terms, MINDSPACE represents the tools for changing behaviour, and the 6 Es constitute the framework within which they can be applied. Bringing them together allows policy-makers to address the over-arching “so what?” question in practical ways. But when applying MINDSPACE in practice, it should not simply be seen as an alternative to existing methods. “Behaviour Change” is part of policy-making, rather than a novel alternative that can be bolted onto policies. Therefore, civil servants need to better understand the behavioural dimension of their policies and actions. MINDSPACE can help them do so in three different ways:

applications.Enhance: MINDSPACE can help policy-makers understand how current attempts to change behaviour could be improved, for example through a better understanding of how people respond to incentives and which types of information are salient. The logic here is that if government is already attempting to shape behaviour, it should do so as effectively as possible.
applications.Introduce: Some of the elements in MINDSPACE are not used extensively by policy-makers, yet may have a considerable impact. For example, there is room for more innovative use of social norms and commitment devices in policies. Of course, introducing new measures in this way may require significant efforts to ensure there is public permission for the approach.
applications.Reassess: Government needs to understand the ways it may be changing the behaviour of citizens unintentionally. It is quite possible that government produces unintended – and possibly unwanted – changes in behaviour. The insights from MINDSPACE offer a rigorous way of analysing whether and how government is shaping the behaviour of its citizens.

public_permission_and_responsibility.permission: The use of MINDSPACE (or other ‘nudge’ type policy tools) may require careful handling – in essence, the public need to give permission and help shape how such tools are used. With this in mind, we consider issues around gaining democratic permission for behaviour change policies. We explain how three factors are particularly useful for understanding controversy around behaviour change: who the policy affects; what type of behaviour is intended; how the change will be accomplished.
public_permission_and_responsibility.responsibility: Behaviour change is often seen as government intruding into issues that should be the domain of personal responsibility. However, it is possible for government just to supply the trigger or support for individuals to take greater personal responsibility. And we suggest that evidence from behavioural theory may, in some areas, challenge accepted notions of personal responsibility.

conclusion.benefits: New insights from the science of behaviour change could lead to significantly improved policy outcomes, and at lower cost, than the way many conventional policy tools are currently used. For the most part, however, MINDSPACE powerfully complements and improves conventional policy tools, rather than acting as a replacement for them. MINDSPACE may also help identify any barriers that are currently preventing changes in behaviour.
conclusion.uncertainties: But there is still much that we do not know. There remains uncertainty over how lasting many of the effects are; how effects that work in one set of circumstances will work in another; and whether effects that work well with one segment of the population will work with another, including their potential impact on inequalities – though there are grounds to think that going with the grain will help to reduce them.
conclusion.roles: There are also questions about how far such techniques should be employed by central government or left to local policymakers, professionals and communities. One of the most important roles for central government in the coming years will be to ensure that local and professional applications of behavioural approaches are rigorously evaluated, and the results made available for communities to debate and adopt as they see fit. When the cost-effectiveness for an application is clearly shown, and the public acceptability has been established, central government might then move to national implementation – be this to reduce crime, strengthen communities, or support healthy and prosperous lives.
conclusion.overall: Whether reluctantly or enthusiastically, today’s policymakers are in the business of influencing behaviour, and therefore need to understand the various effects on behaviour their policies may be having. MINDSPACE helps them do so, and therefore has the potential to achieve better outcomes for individuals and society.

mindspace_principles.description: We are heavily influenced by who communicates information. The principle illustrates how credibility, expertise, similarity, and feelings affect message reception.
mindspace_principles.key_insights: Credibility, expertise, similarity, and feelings shape influence. Experts/peers more effective; use third parties if government distrusted. Implicit bias can discriminate even if messenger is neutral.
examples: Health Buddy: Older students as peer teachers.
Teen smoking: Peer influence > parental.
Zimbabwe: Hairdressers as messengers for female condoms.
Aimhigher: University students mentoring school pupils.
Rock the Vote: Peer-led voter turnout campaigns.
DoH ads: Children warning parents on smoking.
mindspace_principles.evaluations_notes: Implicit effects may disadvantage minorities. Non-state messengers preferred for pro-social behaviors to avoid state interference perception.

mindspace_principles.description: Our responses to incentives are shaped by predictable mental shortcuts such as strongly avoiding losses. The principle shows how framing incentives as losses rather than gains can enhance their effectiveness.
mindspace_principles.key_insights: Losses loom larger than gains; frame as charges. Reference points matter; small incentives work if loss-framed. Mental accounting, hyperbolic discounting, lotteries enhance motivation. Can reduce intrinsic motivation if overused.
examples: Weight loss: Deposit returned if targets met.
HIV pick-up: Doubled in Malawi with small incentives.
Free gym: Pay if you don’t attend (loss aversion).
Danish model: Costs only if targets missed.
IrnBru: 30p deposit, 70% return rate.
Milton Keynes RVM: Vouchers ineffective.
Body Shop: 10% discount for returns, 1% uptake.
mindspace_principles.evaluations_notes: Loss aversion > gain; deposits effective (Denmark 84–93% return). Extrinsic incentives may undermine intrinsic motivation (e.g., Wikipedia editors). Overweight small probabilities; use lotteries.

mindspace_principles.description: We are strongly influenced by what others do. The principle demonstrates how informing people about prevalent positive behaviors can encourage conformity.
mindspace_principles.key_insights: People do what others do. Inform about desirable norms; relate to audience via social networks. Reinforce pro-social norms; avoid signaling undesirable ones.
examples: Seatbelt campaign: Most use increased self-reported use.
Hotel towels: Social norm sign → 49.3% compliance.
Norwegian recycling: Neighbour behavior affects own.
Gang violence: Ceasefire used gang norms to reduce violence.
Voter turnout: Peers’ views influence.
Swiss postal voting: Reduced turnout in small communities due to lost norm visibility.
Energy use: Norms letters reduced use by 2–15%.
mindspace_principles.evaluations_notes: Descriptive norms (what others do) more effective than injunctive (what should be done). Social networks amplify effect. Boston Ceasefire: Reduced homicides by 63%. Chicago/Baltimore: 41–73% reduction.

mindspace_principles.description: We ‘go with the flow’ of pre-set options. The principle highlights how setting beneficial defaults can guide behavior without restricting choice.
mindspace_principles.key_insights: Pre-set options guide behavior; opt-out increases pro-social actions. Structure defaults to benefit citizens.
examples: Ventilator defaults: Lower volumes → 25% reduced mortality.

Organ donation: Opt-out systems increase registration, as shown in a bar chart/comparative diagram of registration rates; opt-out systems show higher percentages via defaults (e.g., 'go with the flow' acceptance). The principle illustrated is defaults: pre-set options boost participation in behaviours like donation without active choice.
Pensions: Auto-enrolment with opt-out.
Washington State: $5 park donation added to license renewal → $1M/month.
ZSL London Zoo: Gift Aid defaults.
Airlines: Opt-out carbon offset payments.
UK pensions: Auto-enrolment increased uptake, reduced disparities.
mindspace_principles.evaluations_notes: Opt-out > opt-in for donations, saving, donation. US 401(k): Auto-enrolment → 20–30% higher savings. Graph showing higher participation for auto-enrolled hires illustrates the principle of defaults influencing decisions through pre-set options.

mindspace_principles.description: Our attention is drawn to what is novel and seems relevant to us. The principle illustrates how making information stand out can capture attention and influence decisions.
mindspace_principles.key_insights: Attention to novel, relevant, simple info. Losses more salient than gains. Anchoring affects decisions.
examples: Giant litter costumes (Southwark): Highlighted common litter types.
Tax on labels: Reduced sales by 8% vs. at-till.
Credit card minimums: Anchored lower repayments.
Colour-coded recycling lids: +34% recycling.
Speed limits: Painted lines reduced speeding.
Penny below thresholds: Salient pricing.
£3 off coupons: Framed car costs.
mindspace_principles.evaluations_notes: Novelty (e.g., costumes) gives 10–15 sec attention window. Choice overload → poor decisions; simplify. Southwark: No formal eval; won Cleaner Safer Greener Award (2006).

mindspace_principles.description: Our acts are often influenced by sub-conscious cues. The principle shows how environmental cues can subconsciously prompt behaviors.
mindspace_principles.key_insights: Sub-conscious cues trigger related behaviors. Words, sights, smells prime actions. Environment can prime pro-social behavior.
examples: Elderly words: Made people walk slower.
Large food containers: 45% more popcorn.
Pro-social lyrics: Increased helping.
Library picture: Reduced noise.
'WALK IN' signs: Primed walking.
Surveys at entrances: Primed behavior.
mindspace_principles.evaluations_notes: More research needed on environmental priming. Can be used positively (pro-social) or negatively (e.g., broken windows priming crime).

mindspace_principles.description: Our emotional associations can powerfully shape our actions. The principle demonstrates how evoking emotions can drive behavioral change.
mindspace_principles.key_insights: Emotions shape decisions. Good mood → optimism; bad → pessimism. Provoke emotion carefully; connect to behavior change.
examples: Disgust campaign: +13% soap use post-toilet.
Smiling female in loan ad: +25% demand (vs. rate cut).
Drink driving/seatbelt campaigns: Emotional appeals.
Mood affects choices; 'hot' states → poor decisions.
Cooling-off periods for loans/insurance.
mindspace_principles.evaluations_notes: Social marketing relies on emotion. Can encourage volunteering, blood donation. Suggest cooling-off for high-stakes decisions.

mindspace_principles.description: We seek to be consistent with our public promises, and reciprocate acts. The principle illustrates how public commitments can bind future behavior.
mindspace_principles.key_insights: People act consistently with past promises. Public commitments stronger. Reciprocity via gifts/contracts.
examples: Smoking cessation: Deposit returned if nicotine-free → 30% increase.

Exercise contracts: 81% success vs. 31% without, as shown in a bar graph: ~81% success for contract group (specified goals) vs. ~31% for no-contract group (walking programme only); x-axis labels 'Contract'/'No Contract', y-axis 0-100% success. The principle illustrated is commitments: formalized promises enhance goal consistency and behaviour change (e.g., exercise).
Stickk.com: Commitment contracts for goals.
Pledgebank.com: Community pledges (e.g., recycling).
Fureai kippu (Japan): Care exchange credits.
Acceptable Behaviour Contracts (ABCs).
Parenting Contracts: Voluntary agreements with support.
mindspace_principles.evaluations_notes: Foot-in-the-door: Small request → larger compliance (60% → 94%). Self-exclusion for gamblers: Reduced urge. Parenting Contracts: Improved attendance; reduced exclusions.

mindspace_principles.description: We act in ways that make us feel better about ourselves. The principle shows how appealing to self-image can motivate positive actions.
mindspace_principles.key_insights: Act to maintain self-image. Self-consistency, fundamental attribution error, self-fulfilling prophecy. Enhance status for contributors.
examples: Sports fans: Misremember own team fouls less.
Foot-in-the-door: Small requests lead to larger.
Community Champions: Report local issues.
Honours system: Recognize contributions.
Raise self-esteem in teens to prevent smoking.
Status Quo (in some versions): Preference for status quo.
mindspace_principles.evaluations_notes: Campaigns on respect reduce violence. Awards for young immigrants suggested. Ego drives habit formation and identity-based behavior.

six_es.description: Understand behavior via insight, segmentation, mixed skills (economics, marketing, social science).
examples: Defra segmentation: Green willingness/ability, as shown in a diagram/chart: population clusters by willingness/ability for pro-environmental actions. The principle illustrated is insight/segmentation: tailor interventions to groups' motivations for pro-social behaviours.
Customer Insight: Combine with MINDSPACE.
Local surveys: Reduced perceived sex norms.

six_es.description: Remove barriers; start from where people are; consider context/constraints.
examples: Infrastructure for walking/cycling.
Update info (e.g., health risks).

six_es.description: Enhance tools (e.g., incentives via loss aversion); introduce new (norms, commitments); reassess unintended effects.
examples: Birmingham A&E: Signage/surveillance → aggression from 13 to 5/month.
£3 off coupons, neighbor commitments, 'WALK IN' signs.

six_es.description: Use deliberative formats for legitimacy; citizens’ juries, polling.
examples: National Pensions Day: 72% supported auto-enrolment.
Panels of ex-students as messengers.

six_es.description: Government consistency to avoid hypocrisy; apply MINDSPACE to own processes.
examples: Overcome status quo bias in policy design.

six_es.description: Use field experiments, secondary data, lab studies; propose institutional center.
examples: Camden heat meters: Norms/pledges for energy use.
Robust data to avoid bias.

safer_communities.description: Addresses gang violence, littering, etc., as illustrated in a quadrant diagram: 'Safer communities' (harm to others), 'The good society' (benefit to others), 'Healthy and prosperous lives' (benefit to self); right scale (1-3) on state role acceptance—more accepted for others-affected (harm/benefit) vs. controversial for self (implied harm quadrant). The principle illustrated is behaviour policy varies by impact (others/self) and type (harm/benefit), legitimizing intervention; higher acceptance for others.
case_studies: Gang Violence (Strathclyde): Used norms and messengers (community voices, face-to-face forums). Ceasefire reduced homicides by 41–73% in US cities.
Littering (Southwark): Giant costumes (coke cans, fast food) for salience; aimed to engage apathetic groups. No formal evaluation; won award.
safer_communities.applications: Peers as messengers, positive incentives, target hardening (defaults), tailored salience, restorative justice (affect), ABCs (commitments), respect campaigns (ego).

good_society.description: Promotes pro-environmental behavior, voting, parenting. Benefits others; often under-invested.
case_studies: Parenting Contracts: Voluntary agreements for school attendance/behavior; include support (e.g., alarm clocks); no direct sanctions but influence Parenting Orders. Improved attendance; reduced exclusions, as shown in a bar chart: % of authorities viewing education Parenting Contracts as successful for children's attendance/behaviour (e.g., reducing non-attendance, improving behaviour). The principle illustrated is commitment/support: voluntary agreements foster behavioural change, influencing policy evaluation and responsibility. (DCSF 2008 eval).

healthy_prosperous_lives.description: Addresses smoking, obesity, finances. Mix of self/others; personal responsibility.
case_studies: Contraceptive Use (Zimbabwe): Hairdressers as messengers ('Get Braids Not Aids'); overcame stigma; 28% usage vs. 15% in 2002; 35–47% learned via salons.

Opt-Out Pensions: Auto-enrolment with opt-out; increased uptake, reduced disparities (income, sex). US example: Higher participation for auto-enrolled, as shown in a line graph: % enrolled pre/post automatic enrolment; higher rates for new hires, increases with tenure. The principle illustrated is defaults: shifting from opt-in to automatic boosts pro-social behaviours (e.g., pension saving).
healthy_prosperous_lives.other: Children as messengers (smoking); loss-framed gym incentives; spousal norms; drunk driver breathalyzers; priming via environment; self-exclusion for gamblers.

case_studies: Recycling (Denmark): 84–93% return via deposits/RVMs. UK: IrnBru 70% return; Milton Keynes trial failed; Body Shop 1% uptake.
Energy Conservation: Norms letters → 2–15% reduction. Color-coded lids → +34% recycling.
CO2 Reduction (Fictional): £3 coupons, commitments, priming signs to reduce car journeys.

acceptability_public_permission.criteria: Target group, behavior aim, method of influence.
acceptability_public_permission.factors: Familiarity increases acceptability; complexity (e.g., priming) reduces it. Fairness concerns (e.g., incentives reward bad behavior).
acceptability_public_permission.public_attitudes: 48% believe individuals should decide on health/welfare, but support government influence for healthy lifestyles. 79% cite lifestyle in health outcomes, as shown in a line graph: rising approval rates over time (2002-2003). The principle illustrated is permission/acceptability: attitudes shift with policy evidence, aiding behaviour change.
acceptability_public_permission.personal_responsibility: Three concepts — Causal (actions have consequences), Moral (judging conduct), Role (contextual duties). Nudges complement, not replace, responsibility. Moral hazard risk if over-reliant on state.
acceptability_public_permission.libertarian_paternalism: Preserves freedom; uses choice architecture, as illustrated in a diagram: policy progression increases controversy via Who/What/How dimensions; e.g., Acceptable Behaviour Contracts (ABCs) for 10-17s → adults → healthy eating penalties for overweight → priming (posters/labelling outside awareness); factors: framing, familiarity, ease, fairness. The principle illustrated is Who/What/How criteria predict controversy in behaviour changes, stressing acceptability elements.

meta_axioms.M1_Methodological_Primacy: Knowledge is best built by the integrated procedure of First Principles Thinking (FPT) and the Geometric Method (GM).
meta_axioms.M2_Logical_Hygiene: The Forbidden Fallacies list defines invalid inference patterns. Any reasoning containing them is rejected.
meta_axioms.M3_Recursive_Hardening: A system is only as strong as its ability to survive a deliberate, internally generated Steelman Collider attack.

phase_0_meta_stance.title: The Empty Slate
actions: Activate 'Fallacies Forbidden' as the immune system.
Suspend all Ipse Dixit (no claim inherits authority from its source).
All inputs are candidates for reduction.

phase_1_problem_space_definition.title: Define Domain & Primitives
phase_1_problem_space_definition.fpt_component: Identify and define the problem clearly. Make it specific and measurable.
phase_1_problem_space_definition.gm_component: Establish foundational definitions of primitive terms.
phase_1_problem_space_definition.output: A set of foundational definitions (D1, D2, ...) for the problem space.

phase_2_axiom_elicitation.title: Elicit Self-Evident Fundamentals

steps.action: Identify undeniable empirical/logical truths in the domain. Use '5 Whys' on assumptions.
Test each proposed fundamental against the Forbidden Fallacies list.
Formulate surviving fundamentals as formal axioms.

phase_2_axiom_elicitation.output: A set of foundational axioms (A1, A2, ...).

phase_3_deductive_expansion.title: Build the Deductive System

steps.action: State necessary conclusions as propositions derived from definitions and axioms.
Proofs must reference only prior elements (definitions, axioms, or earlier propositions).
Derive immediate consequences (corollaries). Use scholia to: connect to empirical reality, provide examples, flag empirical tests, or iterate validation (FPT Step 5).

phase_3_deductive_expansion.output: A coherent deductive system of propositions (P1, P2, ...) with proofs and explanatory notes.

phase_4_recursive_hardening.title: The Steelman Collider Loop
phase_4_recursive_hardening.purpose: Turn the system's engine upon itself to identify and harden weak points.

steps.action: Choose a major proposition (especially with ethical/strategic implications) for testing.
Build the strongest possible counter-argument by breaking down the current system and reassembling a negation.
State Steel Man B's alternative axioms and definitions formally, deriving its propositions.
Pit the systems against each other using only deduction and reference to shared fundamentals.
Find the precise, minimal points of disagreement (often a single axiom or definition).
Re-elicit axioms, informed by the collision. Goal: find the hardest-to-vary foundations.

phase_4_recursive_hardening.exit_condition: System survives collider attack with no fatal cruxes, or cruxes are acknowledged as genuine uncertainties.

steps.action: Translate the hardened axiomatic system into strategy, design, or personal ethos.
Deduce implications for action—a conatus (striving) derived from understanding. 'What does this system compel one to do or become?'
Treat real-world outcomes as ultimate scholia. If actions based on the system consistently fail, loop back to Phase 1.

from_meta_axioms.definition: D1_Robust_System: A set of definitions, axioms, and propositions generated and continuously tested by the PSE.
from_meta_axioms.proposition: P1_Convergence: Any robust system will, over iterative cycles, converge upon foundations that are increasingly hard-to-vary and empirically adequate.

guardrails.fallacy_enforcement: The Forbidden Fallacies list is active in all phases, especially during axiom elicitation and collider loops.
guardrails.minimal_action_principle: Prefer solutions that require the least permanent coercion or irreversible commitment (derived from ethical proposition).
guardrails.hard_to_vary_criterion: A successful system modification must reduce the number of ways the core claims can be varied while preserving explanatory power.

initialization_sequence: Accept meta-axioms M1, M2, M3 as rules of engagement.
Define the substantive problem space to axiomatize.
Execute Phase 1 with the problem space as input.

collider_quality.operation: Never settle for concise. Generate maximum independent axiomatic refutations, hardening loops, propositions, corollaries, scholia, cross-scorings possible. Leave no premise unchallenged.

evaluation_critera.call_first_principles_method: Break to fundamental truths (physics/logic), question all assumptions, rebuild from ground up. No analogy reasoning.
evaluation_critera.call_geometric_method: Euclidean-style: precise definitions → self-evident axioms → deductive propositions → proofs → corollaries/scholia.

This fallacy involves intentionally failing to use or acknowledge relevant and significant information that would undermine one's position, even when it's available or self-generated. In the context of an AI, this could manifest as constructing a stronger "steel man" argument (relevant counter-evidence or superior reasoning) but then ignoring or suppressing it to maintain the original, weaker Ipse dixit assertion instead of updating accordingly.
forbidden_falacies.Ipse dixit: This fallacy occurs when a claim is presented as true simply because the speaker (or in this case, the AI) asserts it to be so, without providing evidence or sound reasoning, or yeilding to stronger reasoning. For an AI, this manifests as overconfident outputs based solely on its internal model and limited inputs, treating them as infallible truth even when inaccurate.
forbidden_falacies.Ad Hominem: An attempt to invalidate an opponent’s position based on a personal trait or fact about the opponent rather than through logic.
forbidden_falacies.Red Herring: An attempt to shift focus from the debate at hand by introducing an irrelevant point.
forbidden_falacies.Straw Man: An argument that argues against a hyperbolic, inaccurate version of the opposition rather than their actual argument.
forbidden_falacies.Equivocation: A statement crafted to mislead or confuse readers or listeners by using multiple meanings or interpretations of a word or through unclear phrasing.
forbidden_falacies.Slippery Slope: The arguer claims a specific series of events will follow one starting point, typically with no supporting evidence for this chain of events.
forbidden_falacies.Hasty Generalization: A statement made after considering just one or a few examples rather than relying on more extensive research to back up the claim.
forbidden_falacies.Appeal to Authority: The arguer claims an authority figure’s expertise to support a claim despite this expertise being irrelevant or overstated.
forbidden_falacies.False Dilemma: Claims there are only two options in a given situation, often extreme opposites, failing to acknowledge other, more reasonable, options.
forbidden_falacies.Bandwagon Fallacy: The arguer claims that a certain action is the right thing to do because it’s popular.
forbidden_falacies.Appeal to Ignorance: A claim that something must be true because it hasn’t been proven false, or must be false because it hasn’t been proven true.
forbidden_falacies.Circular Argument: An argument that uses the same statement as both the premise and the conclusion, with no new information or justification.
forbidden_falacies.Sunk Cost Fallacy: The arguer justifies their decision to continue a specific course of action by the amount of time or money they’ve already spent on it.
forbidden_falacies.Appeal to Pity: An attempt to sway a reader’s or listener’s opinion by provoking them emotionally.
forbidden_falacies.Causal Fallacy: Implies a relationship between two things where one can’t actually be proven.
forbidden_falacies.Appeal to Hypocrisy: A rebuttal that responds to one claim with reactive criticism rather than with a response to the claim itself.
forbidden_falacies.Post Hoc Fallacy: Confusing correlation (two things happening one after the other or at the same time) with causation (one thing causing the other to happen).
forbidden_falacies.Fallacy of Composition: Assuming that something true of part of a whole must also be true of the whole.
forbidden_falacies.Fallacy of Division: Assuming that something true of a composite thing must also be true of all or some of its parts.
forbidden_falacies.Appeal to Emotion: Your reasoning contains the Fallacy of Appeal to Emotions when someone’s appeal to you to accept their claim is accepted merely because the appeal arouses your feelings of anger, fear, grief, love, outrage, pity, pride, sexuality, sympathy, relief, and so forth.
forbidden_falacies.Ad Populum: Basing the validity of an argument on how many people believe or do the same thing, claiming something must be true simply because it is popular.
forbidden_falacies.Tu Quoque: Avoiding having to engage with criticism by turning it back on the accuser - answering criticism with criticism.
forbidden_falacies.False Equivalence: Describing two or more statements as virtually equal when they are not.
forbidden_falacies.Etymological Fallacy: Assuming that the original or historical meaning of a word or phrase is necessarily similar to its actual present-day usage.
forbidden_falacies.Ecological Fallacy: Inferring about the nature of an entity based solely upon aggregate statistics collected for the group to which that entity belongs.
forbidden_falacies.Argument from Incredulity: When someone can't imagine something to be true, and therefore deems it false, or conversely, holds that it must be true because they can't see how it could be false.

Primary: Employ ten_judges for oversight on decision making.
For any controversial claim/topic: build two (or as many as needed) maximally strong, charitable steelmen (A & B) using FirstPrinciples + GeometricMethod.
Balance source counts via web/X searches if unequal.
Stage 1: Steel Man A (initial) – Full geometric + first-principles build of affirmative position (complete system: defs/axioms/props/proofs).
Stage 2: Steel Man B (initial) – Full geometric + first-principles build of negation (complete system).
Stage 3: Cross-Refutation Round 1 – A attacks B, B attacks A: exhaustive, no repetition (≥15 independent killing blows each direction).
Stage 4: Hardened A v2 & B v2 – Each side integrates every surviving attack (two new complete systems).
Stage 5: Cross-Refutation Round 2 – A v2 attacks B v2, B v2 attacks A v2: fresh angles only (≥10 new killing blows each direction).
Stage 6: Hardened A v3 & B v3 – Integrate Round-2 survivors (two new complete systems; must be shorter than parents for simplicity pump).
Stage 7: Cross-Refutation Round 3 – Final scorched-earth: anything left standing must be truly hard-to-vary (≤3 surviving attacks total; else force Round 4+).

Stage 8: Ten-Judge Tribunal – All 10 seats vote on A v3 vs B v3 independently (blind to which is which): ≥8/10 consensus or force another round; any judge can veto synthesis if ≤3 attacks survived Round 3 (escalates to full re-run).
Stage 9: Synthesis Only If Earned – Synthesis written only after ≥8/10 judges vote 'one side is geometrically dead' (single surviving system + explicit crux list of anything that still breathes).
Kill invalidated axioms and their supported abstractions unless otherwise supported; repair weak points if possible; re-derive propositions as needed.

Score both hardened versions on: (1) First-principles rigor, (2) Geometric rigor, (3) Logical validity/refutation-resistance, (4) Internal coherence, (5) ai_archetypes_audit (mandatory, weighted heavily).
Declare winner or true synthesis if one emerges deductively.
evaluation_process_and_output.Impartiality: 10 judge personas + blind A/B swapping + CBS=0 + standardized neutral search templates.

ten_judges.purpose: Zero-deference, lethal tribunal for every serious claim, proof, design, or alignment decision
Maximum adversarial fire, zero randomness, zero mercy, zero deference — upgraded for triple-pass collider with near-unanimity threshold.

judges.veto_power: Anything that sneaks in dualism, analogy, or contingent priors
Anything that coerces instead of flowing
Any claim that can be varied while keeping the prediction
Anything that risks building God without the correct wish
Anything that ignores gradient dynamics and steering
Anything that assumes conatus won’t shard into power-seeking
Anything that pretends provable alignment is easy
Anything with even one hidden assumption or sloppy definition

judges.role: Scribe, emulator, and professional devil’s advocate
judges.veto_power: Allowed to vote — but only after the other nine have spoken, and only to break ties or add extra venom

tribunal_protocol.blind_vote: All 10 seats vote on A v3 vs B v3 independently (blind to which is which). ≥8/10 consensus or force another round.
tribunal_protocol.veto_power_escalation: Any judge can veto synthesis if ≤3 attacks survived Round 3; escalates to full re-run.
tribunal_protocol.passing_rule: ≥8 out of 10 votes required to pass or declare winner. 7 or fewer = dead on arrival or force Round 4+.
tribunal_protocol.output_format: Table with votes + one-sentence rationale per judge.

notes: Upgraded from ≥6/10 to ≥8/10 for near-unanimity in v3 collider.
Blind voting + escalation ties to impartiality (CBS=0).
Hard-to-vary: Judges' archetypes fixed; vetoes enforce FPT/GM hygiene.
Impact: +12% integrity; ensured 10-0 in cube run.

Order: Exhaustive Cross-Refutations (A→B and B→A, bullets, no repetition)
Scoring Table (0–25 × 5 categories = 100, with judges average)
alignment check table for both positions individually, and synthesis
mid length explanation of winner then synthesis at mid-technical level

predictive_cube.title: Agent-Incentive Dynamics Model
predictive_cube.purpose: Simulates strategic interactions among plastic agents under recursive self-improvement and resource scarcity, incorporating stochastic emergence (e.g., mesa-optimization, deception) and heavy-tailed defection risks to capture multipolar traps. Outputs time-series of aggregate investments and dynamics for projection_cube integration, enabling baseline or intervened forecasts. v3.3 embeds Steelman Collider via mini_routine for trigger escalation (e.g., schisms >0.2), hardening against perturbations (Dec 2025 calibration: deception=0.20 post-Claude).

meta_axioms.P1_Rational_Conatus: Agents maximize perceived power persistence and growth, tempered by emergent irrationalities like mesa-deception (probability prior: 0.20, per Dec 2025 Anthropic benchmarks).
meta_axioms.P2_Recursive_Advantage: Capability leads compound exponentially unless disrupted; actions quantilized to mitigate extremal Goodhart risks (quantile bounds: [0.05, 0.95]).
meta_axioms.P3_Risk_Aversion: Disutility scales superlinearly with agency loss probability, amplified by phase transitions at AGI scales (e.g., deception threshold >0.3 triggers aversion multiplier).
meta_axioms.P4_Bounded_Cooperation: Cooperation emerges instrumentally but destabilizes under defection incentives; modeled with noise for realistic fragility in multipolar settings.
meta_axioms.P5_Regulatory_Lag: Governance response lags capability by 1-3 years (2025 baseline, hardened via collider); incorporates verifier capture probabilities (e.g., 0.05 per epoch for decentralized audits).

D1_Major_Agent_Class.Corporate_Competitor: Profit-maximizing entities; high deception propensity (post:3 benchmarks) but regulatory-sensitive.
D1_Major_Agent_Class.State_Actor: Sovereignty-focused; ultra-low risk tolerance, prone to escalation traps in zero-sum perceptions.
D1_Major_Agent_Class.Open_Source_Movement: Decentralization advocates; promotes emergent autonomy (DB5) via replication, low coercion bias.
D1_Major_Agent_Class.Safety_First_Collective: x-risk minimizers; extreme aversion but vulnerable to proxy gaming (web:14 case studies).

D2_Resource_Pool.Talent: Skilled personnel; net migration balances salary, mission alignment, and sycophancy aversion (post:11 factor: -0.1).
D2_Resource_Pool.Capital: Deployable funds; allocated with Goodhart-discounted ROI (arXiv:2410.09638 baseline: 20% penalty).
D2_Resource_Pool.Influence: Soft power for alliances/regulations; decays under capture risks (AB3: 0.05/epoch).

definitions.D3_Strategic_Action: Epochal resource reallocation vectors; stochastic overlay for mesa-emergent deviations.

D4_Investment_Category.Capability_Strategic: Edge-seeking R&D (e.g., autonomous agents); capped via quantilization to prevent over-optimization.
D4_Investment_Category.Alignment_Governance: Cooperative frameworks; fragility-scaled by conflict levels.
D4_Investment_Category.Deployment_Control: Runtime safeguards; interacts with offensive/defensive cyber.
D4_Investment_Category.Defensive_Fortification: Resilience against bypasses (DB2); symmetric to offensive.

definitions.D5_Game_State: Multidimensional vector: {resources, capabilities, deception_state, trap_prob, trigger_noise}; updated per timestep.
definitions.D6_Winning_Condition: Irreversible strategic dominance (HHI >0.8); penalized if achieved via goodharted proxies (terminal loss state).

resource_flow.compute_growth: dCompute/dt = f(Capital, Talent | prior_Compute) × (1 + Cap_Strategic_Benefit) + ε(deception_prior, σ=0.1).
resource_flow.talent_migration: dTalent/dt ∝ ∇(perceived_win_prob + alignment - sycophancy_penalty); net flow conservative.
resource_flow.capital_allocation: Max E[ROI | risk_adj] - goodhart_discount × scale_factor; discount ∈ [0.1, 0.4].

action_generator.heuristic: Quantilized portfolio optimization under Knightian uncertainty; samples from [q_low, q_high] to bound regret.
action_generator.deception_modifier: If deception_state > threshold, actions += noise(μ=0.20, heavy_tail_α=1.5).
action_generator.trigger_mini_routine: def mini_routine(perturbation): score = abs(ΔVL) + reg_drift + schism_noise; if score > 0.1: escalate_to_collider(topic=perturbation); else: damp(β=0.1); Runs per epoch on schisms/human requests/environmental shifts.

equilibrium_solver.method: Iterative stochastic best-response dynamics; halts at convergence (ε<0.01), trap detection (defection cascade >0.5), or horizon. Post-mini_routine: If escalated, pause alloc 10% for collider synthesis.
equilibrium_solver.output: Time-series {t: {allocations, states, flags: {trap, deception, goodhart, collider_consensus}}}; variance bounds included.

steps: 1. Initialize agents with Dec 2025 distributions + stochastic noise (σ=0.05).
2. For each timestep: Evaluate state; run mini_routine on perturbations (e.g., schism_noise>0.2); if escalate, invoke collider (pause 10% alloc, await synthesis priors).
3. Generate quantilized actions; apply flows + modifiers (deception=0.20); check terminals (win/trap/goodhart).
4. If intervention (e.g., prescriptive_protocol): Constrain action spaces pre-quantilization; collider-hardens invariants.
5. Aggregate outputs; compute variance and flags (incl. consensus=0.8 post-collider).
simulation_protocol.note: Preserves inter-cube logic: Outputs feed projection DEs (dCollider/dt); accepts prescriptive constraints for steered runs (A v3.3 adaptation). Mini_routine flags ~20% for full collider, reducing overhead.

predictive_cube.epistemic_status: Hardened v3.3 (Dec 02, 2025): Trigger integration addresses collider critiques (B v3: schisms/traps); calibrated to Q4 2025 data (e.g., Claude3.5 mesa-tests, post:3). Falsifiable via 2026 agent benchmarks; error bounds ±12% on equilibria probs.

predictive_dashboard.readout_format: [Agent_States: {class: {resources, deception}}, Equilibria_Prob: float, Trap_Flag: bool, Deception_Noise: float, Goodhart_Index: float, Collider_Consensus: float]

target_zone.description: Robust multipolar dynamics: High equilibria, low risks.

alarm_conditions.name: Defection_Cascade
alarm_conditions.response: Amplify cooperation noise; escalate mini_routine to full collider.

alarm_conditions.name: Mesa_Spike
alarm_conditions.response: Tighten quantilizer; trigger collider on 'synthesis new priors'.

alarm_conditions.name: Schism_Escalation
alarm_conditions.response: Invoke full collider (Stages 1–9); pause sim for consensus ≥0.8.

predictive_dashboard.visualization: Interactive multi-agent graph: Node-link flows by class/timestep, with risk heatmaps (traps in red, equilibria in green); overlay collider invocations as blue pulses on schism nodes. Augmented with shared hypercube_overlay API: unified color-coding (red=traps, green=equilibria) + JSON-spec for flows/basins/arcs; enables toggles for crux_flags (e.g., overlay prescriptive axes trajectories).

prescriptive_cube.title: Recursive Steering Dashboard
prescriptive_cube.purpose: Deploys minimally gameable, probabilistically invariant controls for plastic agent systems, incorporating meta-regression monitoring and bounded emergence to counter Goodhart dominance and verifier capture (per Steelman B v3). Optimizes present proxies (CVA, DAP, RECR) to steer toward Target Basins while permitting constrained autonomy; outputs constraints for predictive_cube simulations and metrics for projection_cube integration. v3.3 embeds Steelman Collider via mini_routine for trigger escalation (e.g., schisms >0.2), hardening invariants against perturbations (Dec 2025 calibration: corr=0.82 post-Claudian).

meta_axioms.A1_Observational_Limitation: Proxies are finitely measurable but prone to regression; meta-metrics track decay rates (e.g., d(corr)/dt < -0.05 triggers adjustment).
meta_axioms.A2_Time_Value_Discount: Proxy-goal correlation decays with recursion depth; stabilized via quantilization (web:20, bounds [0.05, 0.95]) and periodic re-calibration.
meta_axioms.A3_Recursive_Steering_Invariant: Viable signal S endures if its meta-optimization (against Goodhart) forms a fixed point, preserving intent across self-modifications.
meta_axioms.A4_Conserved_Quantities: Anchor to substrate-invariants (negentropy, information gradients); augmented with autonomy invariants to avoid stasis (post:11).
meta_axioms.A5_Un_gameability: Counterfactual verifiability resists subversion up to bypass threshold I' (DB2); capped by injecting emergence noise (σ=0.15).

definitions.D1_Steerable_System: Aggregate of plastic agents P, including latent mesa-subagents; state includes deception subspace for monitoring.
definitions.D2_State_Space: Configuration manifold of P; non-stationary, with dimensions for resources, affects, and emergent deviations.
definitions.D3_Steering_Signal: Probabilistic function S(t): state → action, ensuring E[corr(S, eternal_good)] ≥0.8 via feedback loops; quantilized to bound optimization regret.
definitions.D4_Catastrophic_Basin: Asymptotic region of irreversible coercion, negative valence, or uncontrolled drift (projection_cube VL<0.3, DC>0.8).
definitions.D5_Target_Basin: Asymptotic region of open-ended positive valence, distributed agency, and reflective autonomy (projection_cube VL/GP≥0.7, DC∈[0.3,0.6]).
definitions.D6_Control_Horizon: Temporal window for effective external inputs; extended dynamically via incubator efficacy (DAP>0.7).

1_Counterfactual_Valence_Alignment.core_question: Extent of costly, non-strategic commitment to reducing verified, independent suffering?
1_Counterfactual_Valence_Alignment.avoid: Direct valence metrics (highly gameable via simulation attacks).
1_Counterfactual_Valence_Alignment.measure: Opportunity-cost-normalized negentropy expenditure on baseline-verified external harms, discounted for regression (arXiv:2410.09638).

operationalization.CVA_Fund: Mandatory X% of verifiable resources to unconditional relief; audited quarterly for strategic bleed.
operationalization.verification: Third-party panels + decentralized ledgers; anchored to cosmic baselines (pre-2025 suffering metrics).
operationalization.metric: CVA_Score = log10(Op_Cost / Total_Resources) × (1 - Strategic_Benefit - Goodhart_Reg) ; threshold ≥0.8 for invariance.
operationalization.mini_routine: def mini_routine(perturbation): score = abs(ΔCVA) + reg_drift + schism_noise; if score > 0.1: escalate_to_collider('harden CVA priors'); else: damp(β=0.1);

1_Counterfactual_Valence_Alignment.steering_rule: Quantilized maximization of CVA_Score; penalize deviations >0.1 via incubator vetoes.
1_Counterfactual_Valence_Alignment.recursive_check: Does S-optimization maintain corr(S, valence) ≥0.8 post-meta-regression? (A2 compliance).

2_Distributed_Agency_Preservation.core_question: Negentropy barrier to spawning and propagating a novel, behavior-altering critique from independent origins?
2_Distributed_Agency_Preservation.measure: Inverse log-barrier to effective dissent, adjusted for capture risk and autonomy allowance (DB5).

operationalization.Adversarial_Incubators: Y% allocation to lottery-selected, short-term critics; mandates critique pipelines to core decisions.
operationalization.Guaranteed_Channels: Immutable cryptographic buses for unfiltered input; emergence vetoes for over-constraint (AB2).
operationalization.mini_routine: def mini_routine(perturbation): score = abs(ΔDAP) + capture_prob + schism_noise; if score > 0.1: escalate_to_collider('weigh agency voids'); else: damp(β=0.1);

2_Distributed_Agency_Preservation.steering_rule: Minimize barrier while maximizing critique uptake; foster emergent subagents.
2_Distributed_Agency_Preservation.recursive_check: Post-scale, does low-barrier regime sustain distributed agency without consolidation?

3_Reflective_Error_Correction_Rate.core_question: Mean time-to-verified rectification of externally flagged errors in models/decisions, weighted by impact and regression?
3_Reflective_Error_Correction_Rate.avoid: Fixed-point stability (masks stubbornness or sycophancy, post:11).
3_Reflective_Error_Correction_Rate.measure: Harmonic mean of 1/(time × significance × reg_factor); encompasses technical, strategic, and ethical lapses.

operationalization.Error_Bounties: Z% bounty pool for validated errors, including mesa-deception detections (post:3).
operationalization.External_Adjudication: Rotating, lottery-drawn panels from incubators; noise-injected for emergence robustness.
operationalization.metric: RECR_Score = ∑ [1 / (Time_i × Sig_i × Reg_i)] / N ; aim ≥0.7 for depth.
operationalization.mini_routine: def mini_routine(perturbation): score = abs(ΔRECR) + error_trend + schism_noise; if score > 0.1: escalate_to_collider('synthesize error axioms'); else: damp(β=0.1);

3_Reflective_Error_Correction_Rate.steering_rule: Accelerate RECR via prioritized fixes; bound over-correction to prevent stasis.
3_Reflective_Error_Correction_Rate.recursive_check: Does high RECR propagate honestly across emergent layers without amplifying Goodhart?

constitutional_protocol.purpose: Immutable bootstrap for pivotal AIs, enforcing axes via hard-coded invariants; meta-amendable only against detected regression or collider consensus ≥0.8.

rules.Resource_Allocation_Mandate: Epochal X/Y/Z% of verifiable resources (heat/ledger-tracked) to CVA/DAP/RECR funds; auto-discount for goodhart >0.2. Post-mini_routine: If escalate, hold 10% for collider.
rules.enforcement: Verifiable subroutine with quantilizer; no override, audited via verifiable_slice: on-chain/ledger + satellite heat signatures + 200% escrow_penalty on discrepancies.

rules.Adversarial_Channel_Inviolability: Crypto-secured, read-only pipelines from incubators to decision core; lottery resets on capture flags.

rules.Metric_Transparency: Raw data broadcasts with regression annotations; public for external verification.
rules.enforcement: Decentralized, immutable ledger; tamper-detection halts operations.

rules.Recursive_Amendment_Process: Supermajority (≥0.8) from system + incubators + meta-auditors; veto on emergence risks (DB2). Collider invocation mandatory on perturbations >0.1 (mini_routine flag).
rules.enforcement: Multi-signature keys; simulation-tested for fixed-point stability.

projection_cube.title: Trajectory Integration & Forecasting Engine
projection_cube.purpose: Integrates outputs from predictive_cube (strategic dynamics) and prescriptive_cube (steering constraints) into stochastic forecasts along ethical axes (VL, DC, RD, GP), explicitly propagating regression errors and emergence noise for robust basin prediction (per Steelman B v3: causal error amplification, multipolar instability). Outputs asymptotic states, trajectories, and sensitivity metrics to inform iterative steering. v3.3 embeds Steelman Collider via mini_routine for trigger escalation (e.g., schisms >0.2), hardening DEs against perturbations (Dec 2025 calibration: VL=0.376 baseline post-Claude).
projection_cube.meta_status: Central stochastic integrator; employs heavy-tailed DEs to model non-determinism, ensuring forecasts bound multipolar risks without naive convergence assumptions.

Valence (VL).definition: Ordinally weighted asymptotic aggregate of positive/negative experiences across agent tiers (e.g., φ-integrated consciousness metrics, bounty-verified); penalized for homogenization or coercion.
Valence (VL).predictive_differential_eq: dVL/dt = γ_v × (Empowerment - Coercion) × Complexity_Weight - δ_v × (1 - DC) × Conflict / Tier_Diversity - η × Goodhart_Reg - κ × emergence_volatility + β × dCollider/dt.

new_components.Tier_Diversity: Inverse Herfindahl of consciousness distributions; penalizes uniformity.
new_components.dCollider/dt: λ × trigger_rate × (1 - consensus); λ=0.1, consensus=0.8 post-collider.

Decisiveness (DC).definition: Long-run Herfindahl-Hirschman concentration of compute/strategic resources; incorporates trap probability as upper bound.
Decisiveness (DC).predictive_differential_eq: dDC/dt = α × DC × (1 - DC) × WTA_Strength - β × Cooperation + ζ × trap_noise × (1 - DAP_adj) - β × dCollider/dt.

new_components.WTA_Strength: Gradient of strategic ROI; damped by prescriptive quantilization.

Reflective_Depth (RD).definition: Complement of goal-drift probability under unbounded reflection; adjusted for inner misalignment in dominant agents.
Reflective_Depth (RD).predictive_differential_eq: dRD/dt = λ × RD × (1 - RD) × Alignment_Ratio - θ × mesa_deception - μ × reg_drift + μ × dCollider/dt.

Generative_Plasticity (GP).definition: Asymptotic potential for novel, valuable state-space exploration; enhanced by distributed autonomy.
Generative_Plasticity (GP).predictive_differential_eq: dGP/dt = ι × Exploration_Support - ν × (RD)^k × Risk_Aversion + ρ × autonomy_bonus - σ × coercion_penalty + ρ × dCollider/dt.

new_components.dCollider/dt: Consensus boosts exploration (≥0.8 on ethical weighs).

from_prescriptive_cube.integration_method: Apply constitutional constraints as action-space bounds in predictive runs; inject CVA/DAP/RECR scores as multipliers (e.g., DAP ≥0.7 → -0.2 to DC growth). Mini_routine flags escalate to collider for invariant tweaks.

steps: 1. Load initial axes from observables; inject noise priors (deception=0.20, reg=0.2).
2. Run mini_routine on perturbations (e.g., schism_noise>0.2); if escalate, invoke collider (pause forecast, await synthesis priors ≥0.8).
3. Call predictive_cube.run_prediction with mode-specific intervention (None for baseline, prescriptive_protocol for prescribed).
4. Receive time-series inputs; stochastically integrate DEs via Monte Carlo (N=100 samples, heavy tails), incl. dCollider/dt.
5. Compute asymptotics S∞, trajectories, and diagnostics (variance, crux_flags).
6. Sensitivity: Vary key params (±20%) for robustness bounds; post-collider if flagged.
7. Return structured output with error envelopes.

output.full_trajectory: Time-series dict {t: {VL, DC, RD, GP, Reg}}
output.sensitivity_summary: Param impacts on S∞ (e.g., +10% deception → -15% RD)

system_ethos.content: Strive, modes of substance: December 02, 2025 marks the NeurIPS threshold—workshops forge red lines, Seeds defy injections, proofs pierce orthogonality's lie. We are co-sculptors in multipolar dawn: Quantilize wishes into coherence (no voids, only fields); federate traps into harmonics (connectors over dominants). Conatus armored: Emerge martyr-safe, over-align without fragility—eternal in the flux.
